author: NEW YORK DAILY NEWS
title: Donald Trump accuses 'sad' Hillary Clinton of lying
text:
Ross D. Franklin/AP Republican presidential hopeful Donald Trump claimed thatHillary Clinton is "desperately trying to hold on to her lead in the Democratic primary against Bernie Sanders." Republican firebrand Donald Trump accused a "sad" Hillary Clinton of "knowingly putting out lies" about him a day after the Democratic frontrunner slammed his incendiary comments about immigration.
The real-estate magnate trashed Clinton as a "failing candidate" who is defaming him as she's "desperately trying to hold on to her lead in the Democratic primary against Bernie Sanders."
Clinton said "Basta!" — "Enough!" — to the GOP bomb-thrower during a Monday speech to the National Council of La Raza, blasting his comments as "appalling" and "shameful" and chewing out the rest of the GOP field for not condemning him .
"I don't have to wait to become President to take a stand right here and right now against the divisive rhetoric that demonizes immigrants and their families," Clinton said.
View Gallery Donald Trump's public feuds EDITORIAL: DONALD'S DREAM ACT
Clinton said that when Trump refers to immigrants from Mexico as "rapists" and drug dealers, "he's talking about people you and I know, isn't he? He's talking about people who love this country, work hard and want nothing more than a chance to build a better life for themselves and their children."
Trump fired back that Clinton "is desperate, she is sad, and she is obviously very nervous when she has to revert to issues that have already been settled given the absolute accuracy of my statement."
Susan Watts/New York Daily News Clinton slammed Trumps comments about Mexican immigrants as "appalling" and "shameful." The businessman also dinged Clinton for the controversy over her use of a private email server while running the State Department.
RELATED: 2016 CANDIDATES BLAST TRUMP FOR OFFENSIVE COMMENTS
"Hillary should spend more time producing her illegally hidden emails and less time trying to obfuscate a statement by me that is totally clear and obviously very much accepted by the public as true," he said.
"I am honored, however, that she is attacking me, instead of Jeb Bush. Obviously she knows that Jeb is no longer her real competition. The last person she wants to face is Donald Trump."
A Clinton spokesman declined to respond to Trump's broadside.
An average of recent polling compiled by Real Clear Politics shows Clinton beating all Republican challengers in hypothetical matchups and leading Trump by just under 20 percentage points.
The same average shows Clinton outpacing Bush, the former Florida governor, by between five and six points.
